snippet: The national birthrate is now about half what it was during the late 1950s, as Hispanic women, who have generally had the highest fertility rates in the country, are choosing to have fewer children.
abstract: Hispanic women in the United States, who have generally had country's highest fertility rates, are choosing to have fewer children, causing American birthrate to hit record low; national birthrate is now about half what it was during the baby boom years, when it peaked in 1957 at 122.7 births per 1,000 women of childbearing age.
lead_paragraph: The national birthrate is now about half what it was during the late 1950s, as Hispanic women, who have generally had the highest fertility rates in the country, are choosing to have fewer children.

headline.seo: Hispanic Pregnancies Fall in U.S. as Women Choose Smaller Families
headline.main: Hispanic Pregnancies Fall in U.S. as Women Choose Smaller Families
headline.print_headline: U.S. Birthrate Dips as Hispanic Pregnancies Fall
